_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Chlorine Institute, Water Environment Federation/CEPPO RMP, NY State Chlorine Manuals
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: In 2000, automatic shut-offs were purchased for each one (1) ton container that is on-line.  When a leak is detected the containers are automatically closed by a racheting system.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Chlorinators, piping, containers, regulators, chloramatic valve, chloralert
_prev_prog_2.Description:
A. MSDS - SEE ATTACHMENT TO THIS SECTION (contained in on-site plan)
1. TON CONTAINER
2. 150# CYLINDER

B.  MAXIMUM INTENDED INVENTORY

    The Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant stores four (4) 2,000 lb. or "one-tons") of chlorine at the "Chlorination Building" or Building 1 located in the Southwest corner of the facility.  There are two (2) one-ton containers on-line during normal operations inside the center room and two containers stored on the outside deck of Building 1. Facing west (toward the river), empty ton containers are stored on the left (South) side of the unloading dock and full ton containers are stored on the right (North) side of this area.

    Also, on this unloading dock at Building 1 there are at a maximum, 4 (four) 150 lb. cylinders or "150's" of chlorine.  Full and empty  "150's" are stored and chained on the northeast corner of the outside dock.  All storage areas are marked with "FULL" or "EMPTY" signs.  Approximately 150 feet directly north of this building is a small fiberglass enclosure that may contain a "150" on line with full and/or empty cylinders chained and designated with appropriate signs.

    The approximated maximum amount of chlorine on site could collectively total 8,900 lbs.  

C. The safe upper and lower parameters for chlorine are as follows:


LIQUID CHLORINE (EXTREMELY HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE)


CAS #    
7782-50-5

USE:    
WATER DISINFECTION

TOTAL QUANITY ON HAND    
8,900 LBS.
SINGLE LARGEST QUANTITY ON HAND      4 - 2,000 LBS CONTAINERS (ONE-TON)
6 -    150 LBS. CYLINDERS (150'S)

LOCATION    
SOUTHWEST CORNER OF FACILITY

0.02 - 0.2 ppm     ODOR THRESHOLD
(varies by individual)

Less than 0.5 ppm    Slight irritation of nose & upper respiratory tract. No known acute or chronic effect.

ACGIH TLV    
0.5 ppm

5 - 8 ppm    
Irritation of the respiratory tract & eyes.
ACGIH STEL
(Short Term Exposure Limit)    
1.0 ppm 
OSHA PEL
(Permissible Exposure Limit)    
1.0 ppm (CEILING)
OSHA STEL
(Short Term Exposure Limit)    
1.0 ppm (15 minute exposure time)
NIOSH IDLH
(Immediately Dangerous to Life & Health)    
10 ppm

15 - 20 ppm    Immediate severe irritation of respiratory tract, intense cough and choking.

30 ppm    
Shortness of breath, chest pain; possibly nausea & vomiting.

40 - 60 ppm    Development of chemical bronchitis & fluid in lungs, which may occur after several hours; chemical pneumonia may occur several hours later.

Prolonged exposure above 50 ppm    
Unconsciousness and death.

Physical Properties and Vapor Pressure of Pure Chlorine

Boiling Point (Liquefying Point)
[at one atmosphere = 14.696 (101.325 kPa)]    -29.15oF (-33.97oC)

Melting Point (Freezing Point)
[at one atmosphere]    -149.76oF (-100.98oC)
Liquid Density
At 60oF (16oC)    88.8 lb/cu. Ft.

Gas Density
At 34oF (1.1oC)    0.200 lb/cu. Ft.

Specific Gravity-Liquid
At 32oF (0oC)    1.468 (water = 1)
Specific Gravity-Gas
At 32oF (0oC)    2.485 (air = 1)
Water Solubility
At 70oF (21.1oC)    0.7% (Approximately)

Temperature    
Vapor Pressure

32oF (0oC)    
53.51 psi (368.9 kPa)

77 oF (25oC)    
112.95 psi (778.8 kPa)

129oF (48.9oC)    
191.01 psi (1,316.8 kPa)

Properties of Concern to Operators and Emergency Responders

Extreme Cold Temperature

Chlorine is often stored at very low temperatures.  Under certain conditions, liquid chlorine may be cold enough to cause frostbite (even through high quality protective clothing), to fog up protective face masks, or freeze footgear to the ground.


Reaction with Water

Chlorine is only slightly soluble in water, forming a weak solution of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids.  Chlorine hydrate (cl2-8h2o) may crystallize below 49.3oF (9.6oF) at atmospheric pressure and at higher temperatures at increased pressures.


Liquid-Gas Volume Relationship

At standard conditions the weight of one volume of liquid chlorine equals the weight of 456.5 volumes of chlorine gas.


Critical Pressure

1157.0 psia (7977 kPa)-The vapor pressure of liquid chlorine at the critical temperature.

Critical Temperature

290.75oF (143.75oC)-The temperature above which chlorine exists only as a gas no matter how great the pressure.

Critical Volume

0.02795 ft3/lb (0.00174 m3/kg)-The volume of a unit mass of chlorine at the critical pressure and temperature.

Reactions with Metals

The reaction rate of dry chlorine with most metals increases rapidly above a temperature which is characteristic for the metal.  Below 250oF iron, copper, steel, lead, nickel, platinum, silver and tantalum are resistant to dry chlorine gas or liquid.

At ordinary temperatures dry chlorine reacts (often violently) with aluminum, arsenic, gold, mercury, selenium, tellurium, tin and  titanium.  At certain temperatures sodium and potassium burn in chlorine gas.  Carbon steel ignites at 483oF (251oC) in a chlorine atmosphere.

Wet chlorine, primarily because of the hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids formed through hydrolysis, is very corrosive to most common metals.  Platinum, silver, tantalum and titanium are resistant.  Experts should be consulted when dealing with systems using wet chlorine.


Other reactions

Under certain conditions, chlorine reacts with ammonia or ammonium compounds to form explosive nitrogen trichloride.  At the low concentrations normally found in water and wastewater plants, this is not a problem.

Chlorine reacts with organic compounds much the same as with inorganics to form chlorinated derivatives and hydrogen chloride.  Some of these reactions can be explosive, including those with oils, greases, solvents, and other hydrocarbons like alcohols and ethers.  Proper methods must be applied in operations in which they are involved.  Safe means of separation are essential.

D. EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATIONS (see attached) (contained in Milton's written Emergency Action Plan)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
MILTON WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT
5585 State Route 405
Milton, PA  17847
(570) 742-3424 (24 hrs.)

George Myers, Office (570) 742-3424, Home (570) 458-6093, Mobile (570) 764-0543, 52 East Main St., Millville, PA 17846
SUPERINTENDENT, Alternate Risk Management Coordinator 

Jeffrey J. Slabinski, Office (570) 742-3424, Home (570) 759-7184, 1021 East 4 1/2 Street, Berwick. PA 18603 LAB SUPERVISOR/SAFETY COORDINATOR, Risk Management Program Manager

The Milton Regional Sewer Authority Wastewater Treatment Plant is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions," Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 on the basis that Chlorine (CAS# 7782-50-5) is handled for wastewater disinfection and stored at the facility above the reportable quantity of 2,500 pounds.  

To assist in providing a safe and healthful work environment for employees and visitors, the Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant has established a workplace safety program.  This program is a top priority for this facility.  The Lab Supervisor/Safety Coordinator has responsibility for implementing, administering, monitoring, and evaluating the safety program.  Its success depends on the alertness and personal commitment of all.  

Each employee is expected to obey safety rules and to exercise caution in all work activities.  Employees must report any unsafe condition to the appropriate supervisor.  Employees who violate safety standards, who cause a hazardous or dangerous situation, or who fail to report or, where appropriate, remedy such situations, may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.  Some of the best safety improvement ideas come from employees.  Those staff members with ideas, concerns, or suggestions for improved safety in the workplace are encouraged to raise them to the Safety Coordinator.  In the case of accidents, it is the plan of management that review of such accidents be brought before the Safety

Coordinator for review and correction of any and all hazardous or dangerous situations immediately.
  
With continued commitment and dedication to safety in all aspects of maintenance and operation of this facility, this Risk Management Plan has been compiled and is expected to be strictly adhered to at all times.  With this commitment to safety there have been no reportable release accidents at this facility over the past five years. 

The Superintendent of the Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant has assigned overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the Risk Management Program to the Lab Supervisor/Safety Coordinator (designated to RMProgam Manager); and has designated the Superintendent as the alternate to serve in the RMProgram Manager's absence.  

Designated individuals such as Operations and Maintenance Foremen have been assigned responsibility for implementing the individual requirements and will communicate information to plant Operators and Mechanics involved in operation and maintenance of the regulated processes, as required.  Report findings will be communicated to the Risk Management Program Manager and, if deemed necessary, scheduled for review.

Communication consists of daily computer operation/maintenance logs, and weekend process control guidelines.  Written memorandums, safety policies/procedures, and trainings are up-dated as deemed necessary for the Risk Management Program to operate efficiently or as federal, state, and local regulations mandate.  All responsible individuals are listed on the management systems flow chart.  (Included in the written onsite Emergency Action Plan).

The Milton Regional Sewer Authority's Wastewater Treatment Plant has one chemical, Chlorine (CAS # 7782-50-5), present at the facility above the reportable quantity.  The total quantity on hand could range as much as 8,900 pounds, packaged in four (4) 2,000-pound (one-ton) containers and as many as six (6) 150- pound (150's) contain

ers.  Two one-ton containers are on-line inside the middle room of the Chlorination Building (located in the Southwest corner of the facility). 

Chlorine is used primarily for disinfection of the effluent water prior to discharge through the NPDES permitted outfall to the Susquehanna River.  The WWTP operates on a 24-hour, 7-day per week schedule.  To reduce the impact a release during handling could have on the community and the environment, it is Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) to changeout chlorine containers/cylinders only during the first shift (6:45 a.m. to 3:15 p.m.) Monday through Friday when the majority of personnel are present at the facility.

A new wind sock was placed on top of the Chlorine Building in 2003 to check wind direction should a release occur.  A loud audible leak alarm inside the building is tied into the plant paging system and, if activated, will set off a red flashing light located on top of the Chlorine Building, as well as the light on the alarm panel in Building 2 (main office building). Automatic shut-offs for one (1) ton containers were purchased in 2000 to help control a leak once detected.  The automatic shut-offs consist of a racheting system that automatically closes the containers' valves.

The WWTP's Risk Management Program consists of a written SOP with written checklists from point of delivery of chlorine into the facility through changing of empty cylinders/containers with full cylinders/containers, and placement of the empties at a specific location at the Chlorination Building.

The Milton WWTP Chlorine Standard Operating Procedure (currently under revision), includes written direction for inspection of all incoming chlorine containers/cylinders for appropriate PA DOT tags, new lead washers, and corrosion.  The container cap is removed on delivery to inspect for corrosion of the valves.  Any container/cylinder not passing inspection at unloading is refused and returned to the delivery truck.  

A Chlorine Change Check

list is a part of the SOP, and is signed and dated by the handlers, listing 19 steps, in order to ensure a safe container/cylinder changeout.  Daily weight of the on-line containers is recorded at 5:30 a.m., and entered into a chemical inventory computer program to monitor chlorine usage. This weight is also recorded on the Daily Operations Sheets once per day.  Management personnel review this inventory on a daily basis.

The PA DEP Operator's Outreach Program has presented training at the WWTP every three years.  Our most recent training was held on July 31, 2003.  This training includes safe handling procedures, review of the handling SOP, application of Chlorine "A" and "B" kits, and general first aid for chlorine exposure.  Instructional training videos are used annually, or sooner if deemed necessary by the Lab Supervisor/Safety Coordinator. Employee participation in training seminars outside the facility is encouraged by plant management.

Due to this comprehensive training program, detailed safety policies and procedures, and experience of the operators, the Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant has experienced no reportable chlorine leaks over the past five years.

As per EPA's Risk Management Programs Regulation, 40 CFR Part 68, the Milton WWTP complies with OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Regulation 29 CFR Part 1920.38.  Guidance from the Chlorine Institute, Water Environment Federation and the New York State Chlorine Manuals have been instrumental in the development of all chlorine related policies and procedures.  

Should an accidental release occur at any time, the WWTP SOP specifically addresses a Level I release and a Level II release.  Level I releases are defined as incidental releases occurring at the time of handling by trained personnel providing there are no injuries.  A six-step procedure is to be followed as part of the emergency action plan.  

A Level II release would be classified as a release that may cause a threat to personnel, becomes uncont

rollable, results in injury, requires assistance of additional person(s), is involved in fire, or may cause endangerment to the environment or community.  A nine-step emergency action plan is to be followed and would result in contacting the County Emergency Services (911) for an emergency response.  In the event any release should occur, a Chemical Leak Report is to be filled out and submitted to the RMProgram Manager for review.  Together, all involved personnel review the situation and correct and revise any deficits in the Policy.

The worst case senario would entail a one-ton container leak outside on the unloading dock of the Chlorine Building where there is no passive mitigation.  The "B" Kit and personal protective equipment are readily available should an incident escalate to a Level II situation involving assistance from trained emergency response personnel.  

The alternative worst case senario would entail a one-ton container leak inside the Chlorine room.  Passive mitigation is present in that the leak would be contained within the room.  The automatic ventilation system would be shut down and the chlorine would be dispersed by ventilation dilution at a controlled rate by trained haz mat personnel from outside the facility.

In April 1996 a coordinated effort with WWTP personnel, local fire companies and the emergency medical service held a simulated chlorine leak drill combined with a confined space rescue.  The response time from the time the 911 call was placed until the container "leak" was stopped was 42 minutes.  This drill impressed upon every participant the importance of a trained response from all collective participants.  The Milton WWTP revised the existing Chlorine Standard Operating procedure at that time.  

As per EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act, 40 CFR Part 355, the Northumberland County Local Emergency Planning Commission has had a Hazardous Materials Off-Site Response Plan in place since December 1996.  This p

lan is currently under review by Milton WWTP staff.  

As a part of the Hazard Review Analysis, automatic shut-off equipment was purchased in 2000 as previously mentioned, and fire extinguishers for a fire involving chlorine (water mist extinguishers) have been in operation and inspected annually. 

The Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant continues to recognize the potential impact on the community and environment should a toxic release occur and continues to maintain a progressive and comprehensive safety program.  This program includes regular safety meetings and training, pro-active employees that help review the safety program, and adherence to federal, state, and local regulations.
